path_1.title: Escape (1948)
path_1.feeling: Lean prison-break noir with urgency and heart, right up my alley.

path_1.title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)
path_1.feeling: Glossy franchise war spectacle leaves me cold and detached.

path_1.title: Starman (1984)
path_1.feeling: Sweet road romance under sci-fi dressing, but the sentimentality overwhelms me.

path_1.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_1.feeling: Animated holiday homily is too cutesy and slight for my tastes.

path_1.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_1.feeling: Formulaic kiddie sports uplift is not my game.

path_1.title: Big (1988)
path_1.feeling: High-concept whimsy and broad comedy smother any real stakes.

path_1.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_1.feeling: Sprawling period gang saga is messy yet intermittently gripping.

path_1.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_1.feeling: Incisive, enraging, and clear-eyed about systemic rot.

path_1.title: Cider House Rules, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Hand-wringing prestige drama that feels contrived and inert.

path_1.title: Brazil (1985)
path_1.feeling: Smirking dystopian satire that I find self-indulgent and exhausting.

path_1.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_1.feeling: Hard-boiled, razor-clean noir craftsmanship I relish.

path_1.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_1.feeling: Elegant slow-burn menace that pays off with sustained dread.

path_1.title: Meet Me in St. Louis (1944)
path_1.feeling: Glossy nostalgia and musical fluff leave me utterly unmoved.

path_1.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_1.feeling: Taut, adult thriller with a wicked hook that delivers.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Fate-versus-love gimmickry wrapped in bland sci-fi leaves me unmoved.

path_1.title: Limitless (2011)
path_1.feeling: Dopey high-concept power fantasy with no weight.

path_1.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_1.feeling: Nail-biting, claustrophobic cat-and-mouse that keeps me hooked despite the trappings.

path_1.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_1.feeling: Straightforward, stoic frontier justice that I respect more than love.

path_1.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_1.feeling: Post-apocalyptic sermonizing and stylized action do little for me.

path_1.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_1.feeling: Spare, righteous western that lands solidly if not spectacularly.

path_1.title: Bringing Up Baby (1938)
path_1.feeling: Screwball hijinks and romance grate rather than charm.

path_1.title: Cop Car (2015)
path_1.feeling: Lean, nasty little thriller with a wicked streak and real tension.

path_1.title: A Most Wanted Man (2014)
path_1.feeling: Deliberate, downbeat spycraft that engages in parts but drifts.

path_1.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_1.feeling: Tight, character-driven heist tale with satisfying grit.

path_1.title: Jack Reacher (2012)
path_1.feeling: Old-school, no-nonsense pulp investigation that hits the spot.

path_1.title: Logan (2017)
path_1.feeling: Grim superhero road trip still shackled to comic-book baggage I don't care for.

path_1.title: Spy (2015)
path_1.feeling: Broad spoof antics smother the crime elements I crave.

path_1.title: Crank (2006)
path_1.feeling: Hyperactive, adolescent mayhem with zero suspense.

path_1.title: Enforcer, The (1951)
path_1.feeling: Tense, procedural noir with strong momentum and bite.

path_1.title: Midnight Lace (1960)
path_1.feeling: Glossy, gaslight-style suspense that keeps me pleasantly on edge.

path_3.title: Starman (1984)
path_3.feeling: Alien romance softness—no edge, no crime, no thanks.

path_3.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_3.feeling: Gentle holiday homily—sweet but shapeless to me.

path_3.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_3.feeling: Uplift and kid antics—no grit, no interest.

path_3.title: Big (1988)
path_3.feeling: High-concept whimsy without danger—too soft by half.

path_3.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_3.feeling: Grand, blustery brawls dilute the crime edge—scale over precision.

path_3.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_3.feeling: Methodical exposure of institutional rot—facts sharpen the blade.

path_3.title: Cider House Rules, The (1999)
path_3.feeling: Genteel moral lessons without menace—sedative to me.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Baroque dystopia smothers suspense—showy, not sharp.

path_3.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_3.feeling: Hardboiled precision—liars, leverage, and a prize worth bleeding for.

path_3.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_3.feeling: Conceptual menace over clean plot—uneasy but a bit diffuse.

path_3.title: Meet Me in St. Louis (1944)
path_3.feeling: Homespun nostalgia and songs—zero bite for me.

path_3.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_3.feeling: A pro witness to power’s crime—tight, mean, and satisfying.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Fate-hats and cosmic rules gut the thriller—romance frosting I don’t buy.

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: Gimmick drug and slick sheen—no real stakes, no thanks.

path_3.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_3.feeling: Tight bunker tension, dented by the late sci‑fi pivot.

path_3.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_3.feeling: Laconic morality play—solid, a touch mythic for my taste.

path_3.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_3.feeling: Post‑apocalyptic mythmaking over grounded stakes—out.

path_3.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_3.feeling: Laconic morality play—solid, a touch mythic for my taste.

path_3.title: Bringing Up Baby (1938)
path_3.feeling: Screwball chaos without danger—shrill to me.

path_3.title: Cop Car (2015)
path_3.feeling: Lean, nasty little chase—credible heat with minimal fat.

path_3.title: A Most Wanted Man (2014)
path_3.feeling: Muted tradecraft and moral gray—patient and rewarding.

path_3.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_3.feeling: Small-town heist built from character and consequence—tight enough.

path_3.title: Jack Reacher (2012)
path_3.feeling: Clean investigation with a blunt instrument—solid craft, a bit glossy.

path_3.title: Logan (2017)
path_3.feeling: Grim, grounded for a cape flick, but the mutant trappings keep me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Spy (2015)
path_3.feeling: Jokey spy riffs sand off the danger—no bite.

path_3.title: Crank (2006)
path_3.feeling: Arcade gimmick instead of suspense—noise without consequence.

path_3.title: Enforcer, The (1951)
path_3.feeling: Methodical case-building against a syndicate—bleak, procedural, my lane.

path_3.title: Midnight Lace (1960)
path_3.feeling: Polished menace and phone threats—effective enough, a bit soft.

path_3.title: Escape (1948)
path_3.feeling: Solid man-on-the-run with credible prison-break mechanics and clean stakes.

path_3.title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)
path_3.feeling: War-movie heist beats buried under space-opera spectacle—too far from the grounded edge I crave.

path_3.title: Starman (1984)
path_3.feeling: Soft sci-fi romance road trip with gentle stakes—no crime bite, no thanks.

path_3.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_3.feeling: Sweet seasonal moralizing and gentle humor—far too soft and sentimental for me.

path_3.title: Mighty Ducks, The (1992)
path_3.feeling: Aw-shucks sports uplift with kids and life lessons—no tension, no teeth.

path_3.title: Big (1988)
path_3.feeling: Light fantasy and workplace whimsy with a romantic gloss—charming for some, slack and toothless for me.

path_3.title: Gangs of New York (2002)
path_3.feeling: Grimy revenge and city rot I like, but the operatic sprawl and pageantry blunt the blade.

path_3.title: Inside Job (2010)
path_3.feeling: Methodical, incisive true-crime of institutions—clear outrage grounded in facts hits hard.

path_3.title: Cider House Rules, The (1999)
path_3.feeling: Genteel, moral drama with soft edges—respectable craft, but the stakes feel padded and safe.

path_3.title: Brazil (1985)
path_3.feeling: Baroque satire and fanciful dystopia smother the thriller spine—style over bite.

path_3.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_3.feeling: Hardboiled precision, liars’ chess, and clean motives—pure, tight crime pleasure.

path_3.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_3.feeling: Hitchcock’s slow-burn menace works in stretches, but the creature conceit keeps the stakes abstract for me.

path_3.title: Meet Me in St. Louis (1944)
path_3.feeling: Sugarcoated domestic nostalgia and songs—miles from the fatalism and crime I live for.

path_3.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_3.feeling: A pro caught in ruthless political rot—clean suspense with consequences I savor.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Fate-goons and romance in a fedora—high-concept meddling that drains any real suspense.

path_3.title: Limitless (2011)
path_3.feeling: Gimmick drug and glossy wish-fulfillment—no credible stakes, no edge.

path_3.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_3.feeling: Tight bunker pressure and shifting control games—satisfying chamber suspense despite the sci-fi wrapper.

path_3.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_3.feeling: Old-violence morality play with steady gears—solid, a touch mythic for my taste.

path_3.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_3.feeling: Post-apoc sermonizing and comic-book beats—thin tradecraft, stakes feel synthetic.

path_3.title: Pale Rider (1985)
path_3.feeling: Flinty western resolve and simple lines—works fine, if more fable than grind.

path_3.title: Bringing Up Baby (1938)
path_3.feeling: Screwball chaos and cute romance—friction without danger leaves me cold.

path_3.title: Cop Car (2015)
path_3.feeling: Lean cat-and-mouse with a live-wire lawman—stripped tension that mostly plays.

path_3.title: A Most Wanted Man (2014)
path_3.feeling: Muted tradecraft and moral fog—patient, credible spy pressure I respect.

path_3.title: Lookout, The (2007)
path_3.feeling: Grounded heist drawn from damage and consequence—clean stakes and believable mechanics.

path_3.title: Jack Reacher (2012)
path_3.feeling: A competent pro sniffing out rot and throwing elbows—solid beats, a bit glossy.

path_3.title: Logan (2017)
path_3.feeling: Grim road western under superhero skin—more grounded than most, still dragged by the comic-book frame.

path_3.title: Spy (2015)
path_3.feeling: Jokey spy spoofing that sands off danger—no thanks.

path_3.title: Crank (2006)
path_3.feeling: Cartoon adrenaline gimmick racing past credibility—empty velocity for me.

path_5.title: Jack Reacher (2012)
path_5.feeling: No-frills investigation with a hard edge, even if the action sheen is a bit slick.

path_5.title: Crank (2006)
path_5.feeling: Hyperactive gimmickry trumps grounded stakes, which is a deal-breaker.
